position.marginalia_text: Achillis furore experrectus Alexander, non potuit dormire. Ca[e]sarem excitauit Alexander: Julianu[m]
Ca[e]sar. Nescia virtus Stare loco: solusq[ue] pudor, non vincere cunctos. Sherlij

X-ref.text: Nescia virtus stare loco, solusque pudor non vincere

position.marginalia_text: magnifica[e] iam Legationes non Sinu[n]t Ergophilu[m] dormire. Vnicus mundi Neopragmaticus.

marginalia.translation: Roused by the fury of Achilles, Alexander was unable to sleep. Alexander excited Caesar, and Caesar Julian. 'His virtue not knowing how to stand in one place, and his one disgrace, was not to conquer' those joined together. Now, the magnificent ambassadors of Shirley won't let Ergophilus sleep. The sole new pragmatic man in the world.

position.marginalia_text: Certè Arma, virumq[ue] scit: Arma, sophumq[ue] non scit.
Polytechnus, Politicus, mundi peritus. Plus habet Alexandri, quàm Ca[e]saris. Aut Ca[e]sar est
Maiori indiget artiu[m], professionu[m], arcanoru[m] facultate. Nouo viro nullus satis est animi, corporis, fortuna[e] valor.

marginalia.translation: Clearly he knows 'arms and the man,' but he doesn't know 'arms and the wise man.' And he will immediately fail, as he is not poly-technical, political, or experienced enough in the world. He has more of Alexander than of Caesar. Else Caesar is without a dictatorship or empire, and for that reason, he needs a greater ability in the arts, professions, or mysteries. For the new man, no valor of mind, body, and fortune is enough.

position.marginalia_text: [[G5r]: Ille noster in dicendo, agendoq[ue] grauiss[im]a semper expeditus, et laetus: etiam in Tragicùs Co[micus]. Totus mu[n]dus no[n] dignus tristi =] = vultu: nedum Corde ferenti a[e]grè, id est, sordidè, et miserè. Nam vulgares isti, pla[e]runq[ue] ignobiles, sordidi, miserabil[e]s.
At Ille in a[e]rumnosissimis negociationibus semper festiuissimus.

marginalia.translation: [[G5r]: Our man there is most ready and cheerful in saying and doing the most serious things; even in a tragedy, he is comic. The entire world is not worthy of a sad] face: still less hardly of bearing a heart; that is, in a foul and wretched manner. For those men are vulgar, and many of them are ignoble, foul, and wretched. But He remains ever lively, even while most afflicted by troubles.
